Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story:
I stood in the hallway, my stepmother’s voice echoing from the living room, “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It means a lot to your father and me.” My heart pounded. I knew how important this tradition was to them, how much they wanted me to be part of the family, to show I belonged by honoring their customs. I could see the hopeful look in my father’s eyes, the silent plea for unity.

Just then, my phone buzzed. It was a number I recognized—the legislative aide I’d been trying to reach for weeks. The text read: “I have ten minutes now to discuss the bill.” This was the moment I’d been waiting for, a chance to push for real change, to speak for those who couldn’t. My activist friends were counting on me to seize every opportunity, to never let a door close.

I stared at my phone, torn. My family’s expectations pressed down on me, demanding presence and tradition. My activist role pulled me in the opposite direction, demanding action and urgency. My hands shook as I tried to decide which part of myself to answer.
